15.58.text: I have a person living within my head.

20.27.text:
To me it’s not a broken brain; it’s
more of a broken story.

27.12.text: There’s a broken link between yourself and the story you should live.

a pioneering new therapeutic treatment – avatar

Narrator: This is the story of auditory verbal
hallucinations – voice hearing – and of

126.22.text:
three voice hearers, who reveal their experiences
and their search for understanding. My name

132.79.text:
is Chris Chapman, and this story explores
the fascinating phenomenon of voice hearing

137.62.text:
– what it is and why it happens – and
how it is being understood, both through the

143.71.text:
echoes of the past and in contemporary medical
practice. What I’ve discovered is that voice

150.04.text:
hearing is not simply about an illness, such
as schizophrenia, but is about a journey in

155.14.text:
discovering how our personal identity is formed
and how we make sense of our place in the

167.17.text:
Narrator: Adam was 16 when he first heard
a voice after he went to collect his exam

178.51.text:
Adam: My GCSE results were not fantastic,
I was very disappointed, and I was walking

183.99.text:
home, there was an old railway track that
you could walk up to to get back to the back

187.07.text:
of my house. And I opened the paper there,
which had my results on, and then all of a

192.26.text:
sudden I was upset, but there was this…there
was somebody there, somebody was… It said

199.26.text:
I was just a few expletives and said I was
a disappointment, I’d let my mum down, I’d

204.97.text:
let myself down. It told me I was a waste
of space, a disgrace, and that I should hit

209.90.text:
myself… Which I regret to say I did. I did
– I punched myself in the mouth.

220.15.text:
Narrator: Dolly also first heard a voice in
her teenage years. It was a Sunday afternoon.

227.77.text:
She was listening to the weekly pop charts
on the radio, when a voice suddenly spoke

233.26.text:
Dolly: The sentence it uttered for the first
time had no meaning then, and if I look back

239.39.text:
at it, it has no meaning now, but it basically
said, “How much do you want?” It started

246.56.text:
to become quite aggressive in its tone and
was saying, “I can see what you’re doing,

252.88.text:
people are watching you.” And I thought,
“Hold on, this is not the radio.” The

259.19.text:
next day the same voice came up again. And
this time it was saying, “You’re going

265.43.text:
Narrator: From that second day, Dolly heard
voices nonstop for years and years.

273.44.text:
Dolly: It was like being bullied really. The
very few times I did go out, they would say,

280.29.text:
“Step in front of a bus, jump down the stairwell.”
It just seemed to me that they wanted my destruction,

292.66.text:
Narrator: The man standing in the rain outside
the SHARP clinic is John. He first heard voices

299.74.text: much later in life when he was in his 30s.

302.54.text:
John: I couldn’t get to sleep. I was in
bed, it was late at night, and a voice came

309.32.text:
in saying, “Kill him, kill him,” directed
at my stepfather.

316.32.text:
Narrator: What’s striking about these people’s
experiences is that the voices addressed the

323.32.text:
hearer clearly, in full sentences. They ordered
them to hurt either themselves or someone

328.46.text:
else and they were so real, it was as if they
had been uttered by another person, standing

334.81.text:
Dolly: It’s like as if they were quite close
to me. And in fact I tell people I could feel

340.96.text:
the breath of their mouth on me as well. It
felt very invasive and very close, too close.

351.01.text:
Narrator: Sometimes voice hearing goes hand-in-hand
with visual hallucinations – the voices

355.62.text:
materialising briefly to the hearer – a
frightening experience that Dolly recalls

361.24.text: when she first started to hear voices.

363.00.text:
Dolly: I was beginning to see, for example,
when I looked in the mirror and I brushed

370.46.text:
my teeth, there was a demonic face behind
my shoulder… So it went from shadows before

375.42.text:
the actual voice hearing to looking like real
beings.

381.08.text:
Narrator: Even without visual hallucinations,
voices can have such vivid personalities of

386.95.text:
their own that although they are invisible,
voice hearers often have a mental picture

392.43.text:
Dolly: I get more of a physical sense – I
mean like if they’re tall or thin or if

398.43.text:
they are a person of colour and even what
they’re wearing, but some voices you kind

404.47.text:
of sense that they are wearing a suit and
tie and some aren’t. It’s a bit like when

408.96.text:
you’re on a bus and somebody sits next to
you, you can’t see them but you kind of

412.23.text:
guess what they are like just from them being
next to you.

420.97.text:
Narrator: The voice Adam hears is so distinctive
in personality that although he knows it’s

428.03.text:
a creation of his mind, he visualises his
bizarre companion as a larger-than-life character;

435.84.text:
Adam: He is the Captain – a World War II
submariner. He looks like me, but he’s got

442.01.text:
a big, big scruffy beard, the old naval, World
War II German naval uniform on. Now and again

448.90.text:
he puts on a daft German accent when I mention
he’s a German submariner. He isn’t, obviously

455.10.text:
Narrator: The Captain, for Adam, is a voice
– rich in vocabulary – that both distracts

461.25.text:
Adam: It’s like having a coach train you,
but a coach who’s an arsehole who sits there

466.18.text:
and says, “Well, actually you are fucking
useless, you’re a fucking waste of space.”

468.92.text:
But if you’re sitting having a conversation
with someone, he’d be saying something horrible

473.37.text:
about them or picking out at what clothing
they wear then really hone in on it, or their

478.13.text:
weight, or the way they look, their hair,
stuff like that – he would just do anything

481.72.text:
to try and put you off. You’re trying to
talk in a conversation with this person and

485.31.text:
you’ve got some arsehole behind you saying,
“Fucking look at the state of their shoes,

489.45.text:
look at that...” He’s like a family member
you love but you don’t like, who you’ve

501.41.text:
Narrator: Being spoken to by a disembodied
voice that sounds and feels so palpably real

509.07.text:
is perhaps likely to get any of us questioning
the nature of reality as we know it and our

513.49.text:
place in it. As Dr Angela Woods, a researcher
at the Hearing the Voice project at Durham

519.50.text:
Dr Angela Woods: Our ideas about identity,
particularly today, are very much bound up

525.17.text:
in ideals and perceptions of ourselves as
autonomous, as rational, as being in control.

531.24.text:
We think there’s a clear division between
what’s inside, what’s mine, what’s interior

537.26.text:
to me, my emotional life, and what’s outside,
what’s not me, what’s the other person,

541.92.text:
and what is the world at large. Voice hearing
can I think call all of this into question.

548.04.text:
That’s one of the reasons I think it can
be a very, very powerful challenge to people’s

554.49.text:
Narrator: John’s voices rapidly developed
from the single voice telling him to kill

560.98.text:
his stepfather, to a multitude that constantly
preyed on his anxieties: how he looked, how

566.89.text:
he acted or how he felt. Some of the voices
were familiar to him – voices of friends

571.94.text:
or former work colleagues; some were male,
some were female. Yet the overriding feature

577.44.text:
was that they were absolutely relentless – a
“non-stop sameness” he says – 24 hours

582.41.text:
a day, seven days a week. And they shattered
John’s life.

588.99.text:
John: Going back, I used to not wash myself,
my brother used to bathe me and shave me even.

596.40.text:
I used to stay in bed all the time, didn’t
want to get out of bed. I didn’t leave the

600.86.text:
house at all. The only time I left the house
was for my appointment with my psychiatrist

605.84.text:
every month. So complete negative symptoms;
demotivation.

610.55.text:
Narrator: The enormous pressure of non-stop
muttering, abuse and commands can lead hearers

617.04.text:
to believe what the voices tell them: that
they do come from outside and that they have

621.66.text:
special powers. For John, this even led him
to question his ability to recognise who was

629.03.text:
John: I was all over the place, I was shouting
at my ma, “The police are after me, the

636.69.text:
police are bugging my computer, my TV.”
My ma didn’t really know what to say. I

640.32.text:
used to think I didn’t have original thought.
I used to think it was all voices in my head

645.43.text:
and I was not part of it. So I had the voices
up here and there was nothing from me. But

650.88.text:
if you think about it, if someone says, “Would
you make me a cup of tea, John?” I know

653.11.text: how to make it. So I have original thought.

675.74.text:
for me not to stop and not... It just shows
you how powerful the voices were at the time.

683.13.text:
Narrator: Belief in the power or truth of
the voices can be dangerous – sometimes

688.04.text:
they can convince the hearer to hurt themselves.
For John, one morning they did just that.

695.78.text:
He awoke, and at the behest of his voices,
walked over three miles to Vauxhall Bridge

700.32.text:
– and without stopping, jumped into the
River Thames.

705.00.text:
John: They were in the MI5 mode, and part
of me thought they controlled me. I didn’t

711.02.text:
feel anything. It’s very difficult to explain.
But I was walking and I couldn’t feel anything

716.03.text:
and I jumped off the bridge. And the next
day my psychiatrist came to see me in hospital

722.17.text:
and I said, “I went for a swim.” I even
denied it was even suicide.

731.59.text:
Narrator: Sometimes the message is more ambiguous.
Voices can guide the hearer towards their

739.86.text:
own destruction in seemingly subtle and deceptive
ways. This can be veiled as a friend or, as

747.15.text:
in Dolly’s case, by convincing her that
she was Jesus.

750.75.text:
Dolly: They told me to go recruit disciples.
They said, “You can’t change the world

757.92.text:
without disciples,” so I went into Morrisons,
and there was this guy trying to read which

765.84.text:
TCP he was going have, was he going to have
the smaller bottle or a big bottle, and I

769.68.text:
said, “You don’t need TCP, you need Jesus
in your life.” He told me to eff off [Laughs].

775.13.text:
But actually I did manage to recruit some
interest. The voices around the kind of Jesus

783.42.text:
thing were not harsh, they were quite benevolent.
Benevolent but dangerous as well, because

789.35.text:
they would say, “You’re invincible, step
in front of a bus to prove it.”

796.24.text:
Narrator: So where do these voices come from
and why are they so lucid, despite the malevolent

802.98.text:
and irrational nature of their commands? At
Durham University, Professor Charles Fernyhough

814.54.text:
believes voice hearing has its roots in our
inner speech – our internalised, self-directed

820.52.text:
dialogue – quite literally, the voice in
our heads.

824.00.text:
Professor Charles Fernyhough: If you ask people
to reflect on their inner experience, you

828.57.text:
find that it’s full of words. People often
say they have a voice going on in their heads

835.40.text:
the whole time. And the key thing here is
not to assume that inner speech is like external

841.50.text:
speech. So we shouldn’t assume that when
we talk to ourselves in our heads it’s going

846.47.text:
to sound exactly like what it sounds like
when we talk to another person or even talk

850.04.text:
to ourselves out loud. To give an example:
Imagine you’re sitting quietly in your living

856.59.text:
room late at night and you hear a loud clattering
noise outside the window. You are probably

864.44.text:
not going to say to yourself, “The cat has
just knocked the dustbin lid off.” You’re

868.84.text:
probably going to say to yourself quietly
in your head, “The cat.” Or you might

873.36.text:
say, “The dustbin lid.” Inner speech I
think often has this condensed note-form quality.

880.60.text:
It’s almost like external speech is the
full text and inner speech is the notes you

886.32.text: make for yourself on that text.

889.91.text:
Narrator: These mental Post-it notes are just
one of many different forms of inner speech

900.89.text:
Narrator: By studying how children play, we
can begin to understand how our inner speech

910.72.text:
develops. This inner speech stems from the
instructions of parents and other adults we,

917.92.text:
as children, interact with. Using language
in this way guides a child’s actions and

924.21.text:
helps to speed-up their thinking. It was a
form of cognitive development of great interest

931.65.text:
Professor Fernyhough: Vygotsky was a Russian
psychologist working in the ’20s and ’30s.

938.35.text:
Professor Fernyhough: Vygotsky thought that
thinking starts off as a social activity,

942.46.text:
something that we do with other people. You
think about a child working with a parent

947.55.text:
on solving a puzzle or playing a game, they
create a dialogue between them, which is a

952.23.text:
kind of thinking out loud. Vygotsky thought
that in time that dialogue becomes internalised

958.22.text: – the child starts to take it on for herself.

961.45.text:
Narrator: So the inner speech we verbalise
at an early age is gradually silenced. But

969.62.text: the dialogue continues inside our heads.

972.02.text:
Professor Fernyhough: There are all sorts
of important implications that flow from this

977.16.text:
idea. One is that the inner speech should
have a social structure. It should continue

982.44.text:
to have the structure of a dialogue, of a
conversation, a give-and-take, a to-and-fro.

989.74.text:
Another important idea is that the language,
as it’s internalised, is changed, it’s

994.76.text:
transformed. It gets cut down and abbreviated
and condensed. I think Vygotsky’s theory

1001.05.text:
helps us to make sense of the fact that many
voices have the quality of a command or an

1005.64.text:
instruction. Usually something quite banal,
like “Go to the shops”, “Get some milk”.

1009.40.text:
Because you are effectively talking to yourself,
telling yourself to do things, evaluating

1016.26.text:
Narrator: We can also perhaps begin to see
a link between the authoritative, adult voices

1022.79.text:
telling us as children what to do, and the
domineering, strident commands issued by invisible

1028.60.text:
beings that voice hearers describe. Brain-scanning
technology is also beginning to offer clues

1036.23.text: as to how inner speech works.

1038.20.text:
Professor Fernyhough: There’s also some
evidence from neuroscientific studies that

1041.67.text:
suggests that in people who don’t hear voices,
when they produce inner speech normally, the

1047.25.text:
bit of the brain that listens to language,
kind of switches off, dampens its response.

1053.58.text:
It’s as if the brain is saying, “We’re
about to say something, this is us talking,

1060.85.text:
Narrator: So in actual fact, we’re having
a dialogue with ourselves all the time. As

1066.51.text:
small children, we say our thoughts out loud.
When we grow older, the chatter continues,

1072.49.text:
but silently within our minds as we appraise
our own actions and decisions. It helps to

1078.20.text:
reinforce our sense of self – a single,
coherent identity that we use to monitor and

1084.80.text:
guide ourselves. But voice hearers don’t
have that sense of empowerment and control;

1091.26.text:
their voice seems to come from someone else
entirely.

1104.59.text:
Narrator: If the voices become very distressing
to a person’s sense of self, the journey

1130.33.text:
for most voice hearers usually includes contact
with mental health services. This is followed,

1136.32.text:
in all probability, by a diagnosis of serious
mental illness and the prescription of powerful

1141.65.text:
drugs that aim to suppress the voices. Tom
Craig is a professor of social psychiatry

1148.43.text:
at the Institute of Psychiatry in London.
He explains the use of medication to treat

1155.14.text:
Professor Tom Craig: Medications available
for voices are a group of substances that

1160.77.text:
are known as antipsychotics, because they
work for psychosis. And they will improve

1166.43.text:
voices, reduce their frequency and their intensity,
I suppose in about a third of cases that are

1172.26.text:
developing voices for the first time. People
are more able to see things as being coincidences

1177.30.text:
or not really relating to themselves. Whereas
when they’re ill, everything seems to be

1181.34.text: to do with themselves and their delusion.

1184.04.text:
Narrator: Antipsychotic medication comes with
an array of side-effects for the user, as

1189.98.text:
John: The side-effects of clozapine are constipation,
saliva in the mouth at night-time going all

1197.48.text:
over the pillows, tiredness, putting on some
weight – they’re the main ones. And also

1203.50.text:
you have the blood count, so I have to go
for a blood test every month now. But the

1209.82.text:
clozapine, the positives outweigh the negatives.
The voices are less intense as they used to

1217.05.text:
Narrator: The drugs are no panacea and their
long-term results are questionable, as Professor

1226.45.text:
Professor Craig: The sad reality is even the
most optimistic studies, we’re talking about

1230.93.text:
something like a half of the folk who have
medicines making a really complete recovery

1235.91.text:
– most of the other half continuing to have
some symptoms and so some resistance continuing.

1241.96.text:
Even if the medicine works, it’s a temporary
fix. It would appear that when you stop the

1246.47.text:
medicines there’s very high rates of relapse.
So even after a first episode of psychosis,

1252.81.text:
we’re encouraging people to take their medicines
for one to two years.

1256.98.text:
Narrator: A long time to be taking drugs with
some extremely potent side-effects. And because

1262.80.text:
the effectiveness is so variable, voice hearers
tend to have quite opposed views on whether

1267.80.text:
or not they work. Dolly and Adam have had
very different experiences.

1273.47.text:
Adam: I am on two different types of medication.
I am on venlafaxine, which is an antidepressant.

1279.10.text:
I am on aripiprazole, which is an antipsychotic.
Medication helped me drastically. I tried

1284.58.text:
for so long without medication, then I finally
said, “Actually, I cannot do it by myself.

1289.25.text:
If there’s some medication out there that
can help me, then please I want to give it

1293.70.text: a try, I want to give it a shot.”

1295.46.text:
Dolly: The first time I was prescribed medication
I was about 21, I think. It was a horrible

1302.15.text:
sensation of being so tired you could barely
stand but also needing to move because of

1307.45.text:
the medication. I could still hear the voices,
I was still depressed and I was still paranoid,

1313.76.text:
and they kept saying to me, “It’ll get
better, it’ll get better,” and it never

1317.58.text:
did get better to be quite honest. You know,
none of the medications I’ve ever taken

1322.47.text:
has taken my voices away, not a single one
of them.

1328.18.text:
Narrator: Jacqui Dillon is a voice hearer
and the Chair of the national Hearing Voices

1334.72.text:
Network in England. Along with many other
voice hearers, she rejects the idea that voices

1339.95.text: are symptoms of an illness that require medication.

1343.21.text:
Jacqui Dillon: People who hear voices are
diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, which

1347.40.text:
is probably one of the most serious psychiatric
illnesses. I don’t believe in schizophrenia,

1351.93.text:
I mean I think that’s just a kind of social
construct. You know, many people hear voices

1357.04.text:
that are intimidating or frightening. Are
they ill? I don’t think people are ill.

1363.64.text:
I think people have maddening experiences
that literally drive them crazy. But to kind

1369.64.text:
of locate the problem in their head and to
not see it within a context, for me seems

1378.88.text:
Narrator: Jacqui believes that, ­rather than
voices being a symptom of a brain disorder,

1384.66.text:
maybe we can gain a greater understanding
if we investigate the story of someone’s

1393.52.text:
life. Back in the Middle Ages, visions were
often seen as powerful messages about oneself.

1407.00.text:
Hallucinations involving demonic forms could
be seen as symbols of one’s bodily passions

1411.60.text:
or desires ­– something to be subdued.
As Dr Hilary Powell, a medieval historian

1419.61.text:
at Durham University, has discovered, the
challenge during this period was not to suppress

1424.77.text:
them, but to try and understand them. A famous
story of such a hallucination was documented

1432.87.text:
in the 10th century about Dunstan, who later
became Archbishop of Canterbury. Doubtful

1439.11.text:
about whether he had the vocation to lead
a monk’s celibate life, he worked as a highly

1444.09.text:
skilled silversmith and scribe. A serious
illness changed his mind and he took holy

1450.17.text:
orders in 943 AD. He built a tiny cell for
himself – one-and-a-half metres long and

1456.73.text:
less than a metre wide – in the town of
Glastonbury. There he devoted himself to prayer,

1462.54.text: while continuing to work as a smith.

1464.58.text:
Dr Hilary Powell: One day when he is engaged
in his work as a smith a demon appears to

1472.80.text:
him in the window of his cell and asks him
to stop what he is doing in order to do something

1482.21.text:
else. Dunstan does this and then this figure
changes shape, so he is at first an old man,

1489.47.text:
then he becomes a boy and then finally he
becomes a seductive young girl. At this point

1497.10.text:
Dunstan recognises what’s going on – he
sort of sits there patiently allowing this

1503.00.text:
demon to shape-change – and then he gets
the tongs that he had been using for his work

1509.31.text:
and he basically squeezes this demon’s nose
with these tongs and the demon runs away.

1517.05.text:
So there is this idea of chastity coming through
in his decision to become a monk, the decision

1525.49.text:
to be celibate, and it’s only after the
demon has assumed this role of a seductive

1531.59.text:
young girl that we have the comment that Dunstan
now recognised what this thing was.

1539.83.text:
Narrator: This story proved useful for monks
who were having similar hallucinatory problems.

1544.76.text:
Dr Powell: For anyone who is hearing this
story, it’s a great thing to instruct them

1551.51.text:
on what they could do. You have got a thought
that is intrusive, that you shouldn’t be

1556.43.text:
having, you need to somehow change that and
you can change that in all sorts of different

1561.89.text:
ways to sort of inoculate the power that it
has over you.

1566.50.text:
Narrator: Dunstan’s story has allusions
with English folklore and the malevolent shape-shifting

1573.46.text:
Dr Powell: A boggart is a supernatural creature
that can take any form that you fear.

1580.00.text:
Narrator: These mythological creatures were
recently brought to life in the film of J

1584.48.text:
K Rowling’s Harry Potter and the Prisoner
of Azkaban. Like Dunstan, Harry Potter and

1590.85.text:
his Hogwarts classmates repel the visualisation
of their worst fears using ridicule and the

1597.85.text:
Dr Powell: There is a lovely scene where they
are first introduced in this classroom and

1603.51.text:
the boggart changes shape depending on who
is approaching it, is dealing with it, so

1608.16.text:
it has all sorts of different forms, which
for everybody else is quite comical and amusing,

1613.17.text:
but obviously for the child who is confronting
it is a source of great terror and fear. The

1619.78.text:
way in which you do it is to change the image

1752.59.text:

He decided to adapt an existing technique

2388.35.text:

2398.57.text:

2409.23.text:
